title: Grade 6
subject: Alternative Content Standards - English Language Arts (2017-)

document.title: ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR GRADE 6: ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTS

7A1A60A3436F4748BA561FF277C27D25.description:
Select an auditory,
visual, or tactual display to
clarify the information in
presentations.

E8E03ABCE66E4690A6E844F887825BFE.description:
Gather information
from multiple print and digital
sources that relates to a given
topic.

0FD56DB767394009A7C9DD80D0A7C9B5.description:
Conduct short
research projects to answer a
question.

88CE9332D62A4AE083BF399508B5E7EA.description:
Use technology,
including the Internet, to
produce writing while
interacting and collaborating
with others.

B6EEA4D39B664C77981BC81553D8A9FF.description:
The student can
identify a word or phrase paired with
a picture that describes an event,
while preparing to
write/communicate about it.

45235748BCE849F2A8CC43E898EE628C.description:
The student can
identify words that describe an
event or personal experience, while
preparing to write/communicate
about it.

2F90CAAD81CA4BB0AE24AD3E8893496C.description:
The student can
identify/list words/phrases that
describe an event or personal
experience while preparing to write
about it.

DE2D98856F60408EB7476A1D9B0E1A05.description:
Write about
events or personal
experiences

959DE935362249E0A636D07960658E97.description:
The student can
select a fact, detail, or other piece of
information that relates to a given
topic.

8EA2461AA18945D79027506511D72E81.description:
The student can
select facts, details, or other pieces
of information that relate to a given
topic.

5425758760A641C5AD827D29869A0766.description:
The student can
identify/list/organize facts, details,
or other pieces of information to
support a topic.

240FD72E3F154950AD5B4AC6677BD1B6.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details

0E9B12ADB9BA4D3584A1F34EDE88878B.description: Students can investigate topics and present information.

F810BFB484A24142A2B5277BCBDD1942.description:
Use general
academic and domain-specific
words and phrases across
contexts.

17318320CD0B4BD99C101C758EBFDFC3.description:
The student can identify
the correct use of language to
communicate effectively with
familiar people (e.g., sharing
information, responding to
greetings, being polite, and making
simple requests, etc.).

B74A99919F0F411383CE783E1D6B1DE1.description:
The student can use
language to communicate
effectively with a variety of
audiences and for different
purposes (e.g., asking questions,
sharing information, responding to
greetings, using polite expressions,
using appropriate body language).

50C197EA22B74FBB914C94ED4D5A2900.description:
The student can use
language effectively to
communicate with peers and adults
(e.g., asking and answering
questions, providing more
information when someone does
not understand the first time,
sharing information, making
requests, etc.).

9791C08BF3FF4B1598EFC4CC81FD53F8.description:
Use language to
achieve desired outcomes
when communicating.

512C1A96E3744A089C368E4A21EB7862.description:
The student can identify
correct use of singular/plural nouns,
verbs when communicating.

CDC8015B683840EF94421A9F9BC3543E.description:
The student can
identify correct use of simple
grammatical structures (e.g.,
singular/plural nouns, appropriate
pronouns, verbs) when
communicating.

45A12F68B4A34FD79595CE177F778AB1.description:
The student can identify
the correct use of personal
pronouns (e.g., he, she, and they)
and a few indefinite pronouns (e.g.,
someone, everybody, many, few)
when communicating.

52ED89D93D0E49DAB6D3987E27A5AD29.description:
Demonstrate
Standard English grammar and
usage when communicating.

3B334B51088D48DA8BB924CE9AB8E623.description:
Use formal and
informal language as
appropriate to the
communication partner.

4C0F92571DBE44C4907D53A794214F23.description:
Present findings on
a topic including descriptions,
facts, or details.

0E765EBB683D4AC98DB56F460A48311E.description:
The student can select
one or more details from
information presented orally or
through other media.

F25095E1A5DB409DA3BB2E839E298E52.description:
The student can
identify a speaker’s point/claim
when given choices.

B357F751AA2C4DC39AB7F55201440AA7.description:
The student can
identify one reason or piece of
evidence that supports a point/claim
made by a speaker (orally or
through other media).

C0AB451D9EB64038818C7D7BE8A25667.description:
Identify the reasons
and evidence supporting the
claims made by the speaker.

5078E18AD15E480D91F672A0B1015A06.description:
Identify information
presented in diverse media
and formats (e.g., visually,
quantitatively, orally) that
relates to a topic, text, or issue
under study

366FA02B2A2B476F941AC219DE5C85FB.description: Students can communicate for a range of purposes and audiences.

D71399C920F344D1A0DC1CC5B27A651D.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions
of Standard English

2738F023B932438495D1623F27744E65.description:
The student can
differentiate if a sentence is a
statement or a question.

3035AB23685C43DFB822C63F329A2ED4.description:
The student can
identify capital letters and/or basic
punctuation (periods and question
marks).

E1939E80F69F456A93A725A9AD680EDB.description:
The student can
identify which word/words should
be capitalized in a sentence (first
words and proper nouns) and/or
choose the correct ending
punctuation (period, question mark,
or exclamation point).

4614499DCA0745C6A236A344134AB81C.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions
of Standard English

BB6A89BE4F39422E9A240FE1C1C8ABA3.description:
Write routinely for
a variety of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

5F8D925D42CE4936AE30AF7A7619B826.description:
Use information
from literary and
informational text to support
writing.

91F2247097044CDF93CC85B9C983B083.description:
With guidance and
support from adults and peers,
plan before writing and revise
own writing.

B2CC2E78803744A999C44792C57722F7.description:
Produce writing
that is appropriate for the
task, purpose, or audience.

522DC1E17014427BB03B6BB155C1662C.description:
Write about
events or personal
experiences

713B662CB83948ACBA4C6C6C0F158987.description:
The student can
provide a detail about an action that
occurs during an event or personal
experience, while preparing to
write/communicate about it.

2E64F411C0214B249B42EC712D529103.description:
The student provide
details about one action/happening
that occurred while preparing to
write/communicate about an event
or personal experience.

22EDA63AA7294B79945B79CF3E284CD3.description:
The student can
write/draw/dictate about an event
or personal experience, including
two or more actions/happenings
that occurred.

4B2B4CE86EED4129A30514A93A291BE1.description:
Write about
events or personal
experiences

9E2E2B435DD843D59EF977EEF3DD2F1B.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details

55FB4BA6503E45BDA3062DE0335059F8.description:
Write claims about
topics or text.

5C4DB095DD8B4B128773376C6AAD6642.description: Students can produce writing for a range of purposes and audiences.

E1858571BF1F42CBB1A791F29AC459FD.description:
The student can
identify a word with the same
meaning as a target word that
appears in a short text.

6ABB0AA4B0454CA991CB70344DBD8813.description:
The student can
identify a word with the same
meaning as a target word that
appears in a paragraph of text

7DD76B06639C46EA9A5428BAF44C7FF9.description:
The student can
demonstrate understanding of
words with the same or different
meanings (synonyms and
antonyms).

18EA58D105F44E158B482AECEE2EEB39.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use

C3441475E90140A4BA04A4DD34735A53.description:
The student can
identify two things that share a
common characteristic (e.g., two
things that are big, two things that
are quiet, two things that are hot,
etc.).

95ADADA8B84641168F1749CF864B4AE6.description:
The student can
demonstrate understanding that the
same word can have different
meanings (e.g., “sweet” means kind
and sugary, “bark” is the covering on
a tree and a sound made by a dog,
“bowl” is a vessel that holds food
and an activity involving a ball, lanes,
and pins).

4FA7B56987EA4ECAAC82A241DE447CCB.description:
The student can
identify the meaning of a word,
words or phrase when presented in
the context of narrative or
informational text. Focus is on
introducing non-literal
meanings/figurative language.

1799509B24724F2BAD1BFAA0DF0B381C.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use

D5C72A4559E14CE583E1B5191AEB0DC2.description:
The student can use
cues to recognize the meaning of
familiar words when paired with
pictures.

20F43757AF1C44BC934C8A8D4601F963.description:
The student can use
context clues to determine the
meaning of familiar words paired
with pictures and/or objects.

EB6FEB3A983A4009A21890AE111F5CE9.description:
The student can use
context as a clue to guide selection
of a word or words that best
completes a sentence.

AD1C37D517DE49DCB55838B1B6B74D64.description:
Demonstrate
understanding while actively
reading or listening to literary
nonfiction.

328FF9621AB94DF49EAAC6483C55EA0D.description:
Compare and
contrast how two texts
describe the same event.

205A91C2A6DB4DECA01A2BBB51582C1E.description:
Distinguish claims in
a text supported by reason.

3C9CDB37D8784A2193A0DF95C276C4D8.description:
Find similarities in
information presented in
different media or formats as
well as in text.

15FD8A9738A348C0A2036C68057E3647.description:
The student can identify
what the author/speaker of a short
informational text said using
word/picture choices.

63925B49D8BD40998AA9568D36F3B075.description:
The student can
identify what/how the author feels
about the topic of a short
informational text.

7B76EE24FE7843498A95FDA599E1E4BF.description:
The student can
identify concrete details in
informational text that
describe/show the author’s point of
view.

53B1EE2F612E4AE9981D62877EE7FA3F.description:
Identify words or
phrases in the text that
describe or show the author’s
point of view.

5594B797777841058E3ED577C6666E51.description:
The student can identify
the title of a short informational
text.

5D38DD5184CA4CA499EAB46B45275848.description:
The student can select
a title that is appropriate for a short
informational text when given
choices.

D88B00EAF86F4B2A894E11164AA34609.description:
The student can
determine how the title of an
informational text relates to its
content.

EE9D82E74DC54A2FAC31A8F9348F577C.description:
Determine how the
title fits the structure of the
text.

BD2DC326F54146B18BE5F27F22B9C56E.description:
Determine how
word choice changes the
meaning of a text.

AC3F4F06541E4ADA93384BB9DC0C8478.description:
The student can match
a detail with a person or event
described in short informational text.

3A7AD9516C6A4F9E9CD4F40DD08D421D.description:
The student can
identify one detail about an
individual, event, or idea described
in short informational text.

511D7554F4944B82B786448851A176FF.description:
The student can
identify a detail that elaborates
(gives information) about an
individual, event, or idea presented
in an informational text.

F7435DEFF1854CE8803CBFFDEF13C295.description:
Identify a detail
that elaborates upon
individuals, events, or ideas
introduced in a text.

E653985C73124B02B124BFBB43396431.description:
The student can identify
the main idea of a short
informational text.

F569C338A49649178528144054282745.description:
The student can
identify one detail that relates to
the main idea of a short
informational text when the main
idea is provided.

58D390573DDF405FB57932C4074A2A38.description:
The student can
identify one or more details in
informational text that are related
to the text’s main idea.

BFD35F2190014A6783C083D20241A338.description:
Determine the main
idea of a passage and details
or facts related to it.

B24AD451CBD74DDA87827B81030D76AC.description:
The student can answer
simple who, what, where, or when
questions about short informational
texts.

E8216FE400A34ED5AD6D53FB28784EEC.description:
The student can use
details and clues to answer basic
questions about informational text.

23C8A1C9CFB64D6B8DF319181B1BDF95.description:
The student can use
details and clues from informational
text to answer questions and make
simple inferences

0279187AEC1C40148C6C3814B3F22E83.description:
Analyze a text to
determine what it says
explicitly as well as what
inferences should be drawn.

7FD7A71C28DE409CAA11AC3D355821AD.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of text while
actively reading or listening to
stories, dramas, or poetry

0A2A59C30D9E4D649708A15E537BEEB8.description:
Compare and
contrast stories, myths, or
texts with similar topics or
themes.

2C089CA1704D42DB8E3BBF3264D03A2C.description:
Compare the
experience of reading or
listening to a written story,
drama or poem with the
experience of watching video
or live performance of the
same text.

8FDA9F6708BA44909C7AC9D3D59AA4D9.description:
The student can
identify what the narrator/speaker
of a short narrative text/speech said.

9A097F9E59CC4D57ADF42CB995B00409.description:
he student can identify
what the narrator/speaker is feeling
when specific clues are given in text or
speech.

28391075653A4583A99EE02C969E813B.description:
The student can
identify words/phrases in a
narrative text that show what the
narrator or speaker is
thinking/feeling.

F859B7E04C8B4598939591EDDA061545.description:
Identify words or
phrases in the text that
describe or show what the
narrator or speaker is thinking
or feeling.

E20A16FAB2414510BD61CDEB5F9E772D.description:
The student can
differentiate between two types of
narrative text genres.

AA7ED528B37C46FBA727832E5BC34B16.description:
The student can identify
a variety of narrative text genres
(story, poem, and drama).

E60AEFF686844EDE8AE72BF681B614BE.description:
The student can
identify the genre of a text (story,
poem, or drama) based on how it
is organized/structured (e.g.,
beginning/middle/end,
scenes/acts, stanzas, etc.).

4BF4FA7BC9AB424DA40D8D498E6B4482.description:
Determine the
structure of a text (e.g., story,
poem, or drama).

153E10B7BAA945E7AECCBEE9F25FD5A5.description:
Determine how
word choice changes the
meaning in a text.

9EB6DAB2182246DCBF65E9B4318B3A1A.description:
The student can
identify an action of a character in a
short narrative text.

7DFB5D879AB04EAAA4012F44B27A0E50.description:
The student can identify
an event that had an effect on a
character in a short narrative text or
how a specific action/event made the
character feel.

1182E905CAFB42C48AA0D833007C5DFE.description:
The student can
identify how a character responds
to a challenge or problem in a
narrative text.

07A4E8DFD1664EA4BD0FA26865E8502C.description:
Can identify how a
character responds to a
challenge in a story.

A1885B1520D64B92B2983E688B2C04D6.description:
The student can
identify the theme or main idea of a
short narrative text.

A94CDB44F3E84800BC2DAF57EBDB3CFA.description:
The student can identify
a detail that relates to the theme or
main idea of a short narrative text
when the theme or main idea is
provided.

721CF071821A41D0843E0EF3F749025C.description:
The student can
identify one or more details in
narrative text that are related to
the text’s theme or main idea.

4A55C907C06143DAA614EF728940F87B.description:
Identify details in a
text that are related to the
theme or central idea.

A2FF2B5C865A4C2499F8A3E594511DD3.description:
The student can use
details (pictures) to answer concrete
who, what, where, or when
questions about short narrative text.

1BCD888052BA48729317F8E57EF6B0F6.description:
The student can use
details and clues to answer
questions about basic narrative text
elements (e.g., characters’
actions/feelings/behaviors/
motivations, major events, setting,
story sequence, etc.).

95EB8B1D138F476A8610F9DE45148659.description:
The student can
answer questions about narrative
text using explicit details and clues
to make simple inferences.

1C01F0A767094A6995843168D4298337.description:
Determine what a
text says explicitly as well as
what simple inferences must
be drawn.

53C985613C484A95957BF9655AB047A3.description: Students can comprehend text in increasingly complex ways.
